p: N. Balakrishnan is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics & Statistics, McMaster University, Hamilton, Canada. He received his Ph.D. in 1981 from the Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India. He has been at McMaster University since 1985. His research interests include order statistics, statistical inference, and distribution theory. He is a Fellow of the American Statistical Association, and currently is the Editor-in-Chief for Communications in Statistics, and the Encyclopedia of Statistical Sciences.

p: Chien-Tai Lin is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics, Tamkang University, Tamsui, Taiwan. She received her Ph.D. in 1993 from Florida State University, Tallahassee. She has been at Tamkang University since 1993. Her research interests include reliability and applications of linear combinations of spacings.

Ping-Shing Chan is an Associate Professor in the Department of Statistics, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong. He received his Ph.D. in 1993 from McMaster University, Hamilton, Canada. He has been at The Chinese University of Hong Kong since 1993. His research interests include reliability and statistical inference.

details.abstract: The prediction intervals proposed by J. F. Lawless (1971) and G. S. Lingappaiah (1973) for the exponential distribution are both simple to use. In this note, we make a comparison of these two prediction intervals based on the expected width of the prediction interval, as well as by means of the probability of the width of one being smaller than the other. For the computation of the latter, we use an algorithm, which is described briefly in the Appendix. Numerical results of these comparisons are presented for different choices of the parameters involved. Both these comparisons reveal that the prediction interval in is better than that in in that it has smaller expected width, as well as higher probability of having smaller width. Finally, we present an example to illustrate the results discussed in this paper.

However, when the available sample from the life-testing experiment is doubly Type-II censored (that is, left censoring is present in the sample as well), no exact distributional result is available for the pivotal quantity in 14.

Two simple, efficient prediction intervals for the exponential distribution, proposed in 14, and 20, are based on the pivotal quantities \$P_{1}\$, and \$P_{2}\$ as defined in (4), and (5), respectively.

The relative advantage of the prediction interval in 14 seems to increase as \$n\$ and \$r\$ increase.
